operation.name: rectangle
operation.description: Generates an unfilled rectangle of the size defined by the parameters. If given an input, the rectangle fills with the input.
operation.application: Creating a rectangle that is the width of the cloth (total ends) and height of your pattern repeat (total pics) and inputting a generated draft is an easy way to repeat a draft or pattern across the width of your cloth. Rectangles can be joined together as bars, tiles, and layers using operations under “combine”.

operation.name: satinish
operation.description: Generates a structure by shifting the first row (described by the input string), the number of shifts specified on each row.
operation.application: Allows for the creation and customization of satin or steep twill structures by shifting more than 1 end to the left or right on each subsequence pic

operation.name: undulatingtwill
operation.description: Generates an undulating twill structure by shifting the first row (described by the input string), the number of shifts specified by the second input string.
operation.application: Allows for the creation and customization of satin or steep twills by shifting more than 1 end to the left or right on each subsequence pic

operation.name: clear
operation.description: Converts all the interlacements in the input draft to be raised.
operation.application: Often used when masking one draft with another, this defines an entire region as black cells, allowing them to function as a masking region

operation.name: set unset
operation.description: Sets all unset interlacements/cells in this draft to the value set in the parameter.
operation.application: Unset cells allows someone to describe shape or inlay elements in a cloth. Set unset can control if interlacements outside that region are interpreted as warp lifts or lowers.

operation.name: set down to unset
operation.displayname: set interlacements of type to unset
operation.description: This sets all interlacements of a particular type (e.g. raised or lowered) in the input draft to unset
operation.application: Unset cells allows someone to describe shapeed or inlay elements in a cloth. Set interlacements of one type to unset will have the effect of specifying an area where no weft will travel

operation.name: set down to unset
operation.displayname: set interlacements of type to unset...
operation.description: This sets all interlacements of a particular type (e.g. raised or lowered) in the input draft to unset
operation.application: Unset cells allows someone to describe shapeed or inlay elements in a cloth. Set interlacements of one type to unset will have the effect of specifying an area where no weft will travel

operation.name: apply materials
operation.description: Adds information to the draft that represents the materials and warp- and weft-systems that will be associated with the draft
operation.application: Complex weavers often generate structures that consider each warp and weft as a logical system that will behave differently in different regions of the cloth. Thus, some operations, like layer notation, require systems to be specified in order to compute complex structures that obey the systems of warps and wefts over the cloth. Applying materials allows one to visualize the relationship between the draft and the color effects visible on the cloth's surface

operation.name: invert
operation.description: Inverts the draft so that raised warp ends become weft picks and weft pics become raised warp ends.
operation.application: Swaps the faces of the cloth, moving the front to back and back to front.

operation.name: flip
operation.description: Generates an output draft that mirrors the input draft from left to right and/or top to bottom as the parameters indicate.
operation.application: Can be used to create structures that include rotations of a basic motif

operation.name: shift
operation.description: Generates an output that is shifted to the left and top by the number of warp ends and weft pics specified in the parameters.
operation.application: Creates a version of a draft that is structurally identical, but has the placement of interlacements fine tuned in relation to other structures

operation.name: slope
operation.description: Shifts every nth pic by the vaule given in ends
operation.application: We do not know of an existing reason, but essentially slants the input draft, which can be fun

operation.name: undulatewefts
operation.description: Given a user specified input of a series of number, it shifts every pic by the vaule specified in the corresponding location of the user specified input. For example, if 1 3 1 is entered, it shifts the first pic to the right by 1, second to the right by 3, third by 1
operation.application: This can be used to create structures that repond to non-linear shift patterns. It could also allow someone to enter a data stream into the input field representing data values, and have the structures generated reflect those values

operation.name: undulatewarps
operation.description: Given a user specified input of a series of number, it shifts every end by the vaule specified in the corresponding location of the user specified input. For example, if 1 3 1 is entered, it shifts the first end to the down by 1, second to the down by 3, third down by 1
operation.application: This can be used to create structures that repond to non-linear shift patterns. It could also allow someone to enter a data stream into the input field representing data values, and have the structures generated reflect those values

operation.name: rotate
operation.description: Generates an output draft that is the same as the input draft, but rotated by the amount specified
operation.application: To create patterns and motifs that involve a rotated element

operation.name: makesymmetric
operation.description: Rotates and 'stamps' the input draft around a corner, creating rotational symmetry around the selected point according to the parameters described below.
operation.application: to create structures with rotational symmetry

operation.name: interlace
operation.description: Creates a new draft by taking one pic from each input and assigning them to sucessive pics in the output draft.
operation.application: Combines two structures into a compound structure. For instance, for overshot, you might interlace a tabby into a floating structure, the alteranting tabby pics would add structure, the floats would add surface color and texture

operation.name: deinterlace
operation.description: Creates multiple draft by splitting each pic from the input and assigning it to separate drafts. If the factor of two, two drafts are created. The first with all the odd pics and the send with all the even. If 3 is selected, three drafts are created, and so on
operation.application: Not sure, but perhaps it is interesting for the purposes of analysing a draft structure or splitting apart layered drafts into their component layer patterns

operation.name: interlacewarps
operation.description: Creates a new draft by taking one end from each input and assigning them to sucessive ends in the output draft.
operation.application: Combines two structures into a compound structure.

operation.name: splice in wefts
operation.description: Splices the pics of the second input draft into the first. You can use the parameters to describe if you want the entire draft spliced in, or to splice the draft in pic by pic and the amount of pics between each insertion.
operation.application: Can be used when you need to insert a material with a certain property (say elastic) even so many pics to control the level of stretch. Alterantively, pics can be inserted to bind layers together

operation.name: splice in warps
operation.description: Splices the ends of the second input draft into the first. You can use the parameters to describe if you want the entire draft spliced in, or to splice the draft in end by end and the amount of ends between each insertion.
operation.application: Warp-wise splicing can be used to add a specific textual feature to the length of the cross in even intervals

operation.name: assign systems
operation.description: Given a user specified pattern for the weft (a b c) and warp systems (1 2 3), this function will create a draft that follows those system patterns and then map the input draft to the system specified.
operation.application: While the same function could be achieved with layer notation, this might be a simpler way to assign drafts to systems while having control over the system order across multiple drafts, ensuring alignment. It can also be helpful for making systems without having to edit the system assignments directly on a draft

operation.name: notation
operation.description: Developed in collaboration with Kathryn Walters, this operation uses a notation system to assign drafts to different warp and weft patterns on different layers of cloth. Layers are represented by () so (1a)(2b) puts warp 1 and weft a on layer 1, warp 2 and weft b on layer 2. This function is slightly different than notation (assign by system) because it will apply a single input draft across all systems associated with a layer.
operation.application: This is used to create differetn structures, with different layer relationships, across an entire cloth. It becomes especially powerful with one changes layer numbers. For example (a1b2)(c2) will place the first layer across two systems, and the second layer across one system. This means that one can arbitrary change both layer order, as well as the association of different warp and weft systems to different layers across different regions of the cloth.

operation.name: notation_system
operation.description: Developed in collaboration with Kathryn Walters, this operation uses a notation system to assign drafts to different warp and weft patterns on different layers of cloth. Layers are represented by () so (1a)(2b) puts warp 1 and weft a on layer 1, warp 2 and weft b on layer 2. This function is slightly different than notation (assign by layer) because it lets you assign drafts to each individual system within a layer (instead of to the layer as a whole)
operation.application: This is used to create differetn structures, with different layer relationships, across an entire cloth. It becomes especially powerful with one changes layer numbers. For example (a1b2)(c2) will place the first layer across two systems, and the second layer across one system. This means that one can arbitrary change both layer order, as well as the association of different warp and weft systems to different layers across different regions of the cloth.

operation.name: layer
operation.description: Creates a draft in which each input is assigned to a layer in a multilayered structure. Assigns the first input to the top layer and so on.
operation.application: To arrange different structures on different layers

operation.name: selvedge
operation.description: Adds a selvedge of so many ends on both sides of the input draft, 'draft.' The second input, 'selvedge,' determines the selvedge pattern, and if none is given, a selvedge is generated.
operation.application: Adding selvedges to the sides of the cloth maintains clean edges

operation.name: overlay
operation.description: Applies binary math to two drafts. To do so, it looks at each interlacement in input drafts a and b. If either interlacement a or b are marked as warp lifted, the resulting draft will have a warp raised in that location.
operation.application: No esablished application, but a fun way to see how to apply binary math to the production of drafts. Retains the pattern of raised warp ends (black cells) from each input draft when they are overlaid. (Keeps any region that is marked black/true in either draft)

operation.name: overlay_multiple
operation.description: This function will take the lifted heddles within each draft and combine them to make a composite draft whereby each draft can be understood to be overlayed upon eachother. The resulting draft size is recalculated in order to ensure equal repeats
operation.application: Can be a useful way to think about the composite structures as independent units, which can then be combined into a composite draft

operation.name: atop
operation.description: Applies binary math to two drafts. To do so, it looks at each interlacement in input drafts a and b. If a is marked warp raised and b marked warp lowered, or vice versa, it sets the corresponding interlacement in the output draft to warp raised.
operation.application: No esablished application, but a fun way to see how to apply binary math to the production of drafts.

operation.name: cutout
operation.description: Applies binary math to two drafts. To do so, it looks at each interlacement in input drafts a and b. If a and b are both marked as having warped raised, it changes the value to warp lowered, effectively cutting the black cells in b from a. This is the opposite of mask
operation.application: No esablished application, but a fun way to see how to apply binary math to the production of drafts.

operation.name: diff
operation.description: Applies binary math to two drafts. To do so, it looks at each interlacement in input drafts a and b and it returns a black cell in any location where the two draft cells were different
operation.application: No esablished application, but a fun way to see how to apply binary math to the production of drafts. Diffs are widly used in computation to compare how two things are similar or different

operation.name: mask
operation.description: Applies binary math to two drafts. To do so, it looks at each interlacement in input drafts a and b  If a is marked warp raised and b marked warp raised, it sets the corresponding interlacement in the output draft to warp raised. Otherwise, the interlacement is marked warp lowered. This effectively masks draft a with draft b
operation.application: No esablished application, but a fun way to see how to apply binary math to the production of drafts. Retains input draft b in regions where input draft a has raised warp ends (black cells); draft b is only retained within the area of draft a.

operation.name: sine
operation.description: Samples a sine wave at a rate specified by the the interval parameter, and stretches the wave to the size of amplitude. Converts this wave to a draft by marking a warp raised in any location where the wave is present
operation.application: No esablished application, but an interesting way to create threadings and threadlings for interesting looking drawdowns

operation.name: sawtooth
operation.description: Creates a sawtooth pattern (e.g. mountain/valley zigzag) of a user specified width with a user specified number of teeth in the sawtooth as described by the segments parameter
operation.application: Can be used to generated pointed threadings and treadlings

operation.name: fill
operation.description: Fills black cells of the first input, “pattern,” with the draft specified by the second input, and the white cells with draft specified by the third input.
operation.application: Fill can be used to create graphic regions on cloth. For instance, the input draft can contain a simple graphic drawn in black/warp raised cells, the fill operation then, can fill the black cells with a structure, such as a shaded satin, so that the heart is visible and well structured on the resulting cloth.

operation.name: tabbyder
operation.description: Also known as plain weave. Plain weave is one of the most basic weave structures in which each weft thread passes over one warp end and under one warp end; the next weft pick follows the pattern on the alternate warp threads (over/under/over/under). Tabby variations include basket weave, rib weave, and rep weave. These dervicatives can be generated by modifying the parameters
operation.application: Generates a tabby or tabby derivative structure that can be modified as needed as ones design evolves.

operation.name: twill
operation.description: In this context, a complex twill is a straight twill with multiple ratios of interlacement in a single structure unit so that a 2 2 3 3 pattern describes a structure with two raised warp ends, two lowered ends, three raised ends, and three lowered ends. Each successive pic begins the same pattern of interlacement on an adjacent warp end, creating a diagonal pattern.
operation.application: Generates a twill or twill derivative structure that can be modified as needed as ones design evolves.

operation.name: waffleish
operation.description: Waffle weave is a twill-based structure in which warp and weft floats of increasing and then decreasing lengths are bound by a border of tabby interlacements to create a grid of cells. There is typically an equal number of pics and ends in a single pattern unit. This operation generates waffle-type structures, but also creates something strange when given uneven pics and ends, or more than one border of tabby interlacements
operation.application: Generates a waffle or waffle-inspired structure that can be modified as needed as ones design evolves.

operation.name: waffle
operation.description: Waffle weave is a twill-based structure in which warp and weft floats of increasing and then decreasing lengths are bound by a border of tabby interlacements to create a grid of cells. There is typically an equal number of pics and ends in a single pattern unit. This operation generates waffle structures based on specifying the longest float and number of binding rows to surround each waffle.
operation.application: Generates a waffle  structure that can be modified as needed as ones design evolves.

operation.name: complextwill
operation.description: Twill is a family of weave structures in which weft picks pass over or under one or more warp threads in a repeating pattern (i.e. 1/3, 2/2, or 3/1). The same interlacement sequence begins on an adjacent warp end, either to the left or right, in the next weft row, creating a diagonal pattern of interlacement.
operation.application: Generates a complex twill structure that can be modified as needed as ones design evolves.

operation.name: satin
operation.description: Satin is a family of weave structures that create cloth with weft floats on one face of the fabric and warp floats on the other. The succeeding interlacements of warp and weft threads in each row occur on non-adjacent warp threads, creating a smooth surface of floating threads on each face. The number of ends between succeeding warp interlacements is consistent in each row (i.e. a 1/8 satin will have one raised warp end followed by a weft float over 8 warp ends in each row).
operation.application: Generates a satin structure that can be modified as needed as ones design evolves.

operation.name: shaded_satin
operation.description: Satin is a family of weave structures that create cloth with weft floats on one face of the fabric and warp floats on the other. The succeeding interlacements of warp and weft threads in each row occur on non-adjacent warp threads, creating a smooth surface of floating threads on each face. The number of ends between succeeding warp interlacements is consistent in each row (i.e. a 1/8 satin will have one raised warp end followed by a weft float over 8 warp ends in each row). Shaded satins typically use more than just one raised warp on each pic to control the visiblity of the warp or weft colors proportionally
operation.application: Generates a satin or shaded satin structure that can be modified as needed as ones design evolves.

operation.name: random
operation.description: Generates a draft of the size specified where the value of each interlacement is generated randomly.
operation.application: We don't know of current random draft generators, so this one is just for the fun of applying code-based random number generators to weaving structures

operation.name: combos
operation.description: This structure operation was prompted by a question from weaver and AdaCAD collaborator Marianne Fairbanks who wanted to implement an algorithm to find every possible structure for an N x N draft. The motivation was largely based on the observance that three structures are said to be the core of all weaving: satin, twill and tabby. M wanted to know why these three? What other options were there? And what might be possible in these other options. This algorithm revealed that there are 102 possible 3x3 structures and 22874 possible 4x4 structures (though some structures are rotations, reflections, and shifts of others, leading us to questions of definition of equivalency in structures).
operation.application: Allows one to systematically explore all possible drafts, just for the sake of it

operation.name: stretch
operation.description: Repeats each warp and/or weft by the values given in the parameters.
operation.application: Most often, stretch can be used to resize a structure to ensure that it weaves square

operation.name: resize
operation.description: Stretches or compresses the draft to fit the boundary defined by the values given in the parameters. It does so by adding or removing whole pics and ends every in constent intervals.
operation.application: Resize can help one convert artwork to a boundary size different then what was originally intended. We suggest playing with the boundary size until the resize generates a desirable draft

operation.name: margin
operation.description: When the second inlet is unfilled, it adds a margin of unset threads to the top, right, bottom, and/or left. If the second inlet has a draft, the margin is filled with the pattern of the draft specified
operation.application: Adds borders of a given structure to rectangular blocks, perhaps to maintain consistent packing as one samples various structures across the width of the cloth.

operation.name: crop
operation.description: Crops the structure or pattern to a region of the input draft. The crop size and placement are defined by the parameters
operation.application: To pick a section out of a draft that you might want to modify

operation.name: trim
operation.description: Trims off the edges of an input draft according to the parameters described below.
operation.application: Can be used to trim off the edges of the draft that might not repeat nicely

operation.name: warp_profile
operation.description: Given a series of letters (a b c), this operation will associate a draft with each letter, and then arrange those drafts from left to right following the pattern order
operation.application: Can be used for profile drafting and describing repeating patterns across the cloth.

operation.name: weft_profile
operation.description: Given a series of letters (a b c), this operation will associate a draft with each letter, and then arrange following the pattern order
operation.application: Can be used for profile drafting and describing repeating patterns along the length the cloth.

operation.name: sample_width
operation.description: Given a series of letters and numbers (a100 b200 c300), this operation will associate a draft with each letter, and then arrange those drafts from left to right following the pattern order. The numbers next to each letter describe the number of ends upon which the specified pattern should be repeated
operation.application: Can be used for creating several sample swatches across the width of the cloth

operation.name: sample_length
operation.description: Given a series of letters and numbers (a100 b200 c300), this operation will associate a draft with each letter, and then arrange those drafts following the pattern order. The numbers next to each letter describe the number of pics upon which the specified pattern should be repeated
operation.application: Can be used for creating several sample swatches across the length of the cloth

operation.name: tile
operation.description: Repeats the input block along the warp and weft according to the parameters described below.
operation.application: Can be used to repeat a pattern across the cloth a specified number of times

operation.name: chaos
operation.description: Made in collaboration Jacqueline Wernimont, Molly Morin and Nikki Stevens. Tiles the input drafts, randomly selecting which draft to place at which position
operation.application: No specific application, just creates some nice tilings

operation.name: bind weft floats
operation.description: Adds interlacements to weft floats over the user specified length
operation.application: To automatically find and bind long floats in a design

operation.name: bind warp floats
operation.description: Adds interlacements to warp floats over the user specified length
operation.application: To automatically find and bind long floats in a design

operation.name: erase blank rows
operation.description: Erases any rows that are entirely unset.
operation.application: Blank rows can emerge when working across multiple systems. Erasing blank rows, then, can speed up weaving by avoiding picing blank rows

operation.name: join top
operation.description: Joins drafts assigned to the drafts input together from bottom to top.
operation.application: To arrange different structures across rows

operation.name: join left
operation.description: Joins drafts assigned to the drafts input together from left to right.
operation.application: To arrange different structures across columns

operation.name: dynamicjoinleft
operation.description: Subdivides the width (number of ends) of the draft into equal-sized sections, then, takes each input draft and assigns it a division from left to right.
operation.application: Simplifies the ability to evenly split structures, side by side, across a particular number of ends

operation.name: dynamicjointop
operation.description: Subdivides the length (number of pics) of the draft into equal-sized sections, then, takes each input draft and assigns it a division
operation.application: Simplifies the ability to evenly split structures, one ontop of another, across a particular number of pics

operation.name: bwimagemap
operation.description: Uploads a draft from an image into AdaCAD
operation.application: To upload drafts from other sources into the workspace

operation.name: imagemap
operation.description: Uploads an image and creates an input for each color found in the image. Assigning a draft to the color fills the color region with the selected draft.
operation.application: Can be used to create complex woven motifs or images with regions filled with different structures

operation.name: germanify
operation.description: Uses machine learning to edit the input draft based on common patterns found in a set of German Weave drafts.
operation.application: No particular application, just curious

operation.name: crackle-ify
operation.description: Uses machine learning to edit the input draft based on common patterns found in a set of Crackle Weave drafts.
operation.application: No particular application, just curious

operation.name: direct loom
operation.displayname: generate direct tie loom threading and lift plan
operation.description: Uses the input draft as drawdown and generates a threading and lift plan pattern
operation.application: To create threading and treadlings plans from drawdowns

operation.name: floor loom
operation.displayname: generate floor loom threading and treadling
operation.description: Uses the input draft as drawdown and generates a threading and lift plan pattern
operation.application: To create threading and treadlings plans from drawdowns

operation.name: drawdown
operation.displayname: make drawdown from threading, tieup, and treadling
operation.description: Create a drawdown from the input drafts (order 1. threading, 2. tieup, 3.treadling)
operation.application: To create drawdown from from a floor loom plan

operation.name: directdrawdown
operation.displayname: make drawdown from threading and lift plan
operation.description: Create a drawdown from the input drafts (order 1. threading, 2. tieup, 3.lift plan)
operation.application: To create drawdown from from a direct loom plan

param.name: ends
param.description: the number of warp ends to use in the resulting draft

param.name: pics
param.description: the number of weft pics to use in the resulting draft

param.name: raised/lowered
param.description: toggles interlacements between selecting warp raised or warp lowered

param.name: calculate repeats
param.description: automatically repeats the input drafts by the amount neccessary to ensure that each draft repeats in even intervals

param.name: shift ends
param.description: shifts the draft a certain number of ends

param.name: shift pics
param.description: shifts the draft a certain number of pics

param.name: warps raised
param.description: the number of warp ends to have lifted in the first pic

param.name: warps lowered
param.description: the number of warp ends to keep lowered in the first pic

param.name: S/Z
param.description: defines the direction of the sequential pattern shift

param.name: facing
param.description: toggle the warps raised and lowered so that the structure is more warp-facing or weft-facing.

dynamic_description: This is a dyanmic operation, meaning that one of the parameters generates multiple 'inlets' to the function. Changing that parameter adds or changes the number of inlets). Each inlet can accept a draft and associate a particular value with that draft.
